Sure! Based on the information you provided, here is an example of how a blockchain-based crowd-sourcing tool for gathering and sharing user-device feedback on coverage information could work:

1. Identify the type of blockchain: For this example, let's use a public blockchain like Ethereum. Ethereum is a popular choice for building decentralized applications because it provides a robust smart contract platform and is widely used and supported.
2. Determine the data that will be collected and shared: The tool will collect data from user devices about their location and the quality of the wireless signal they are receiving. This data will be encrypted and stored on the blockchain, so that it can be shared with other users in a privacy-aware manner.
3. Design the user interface: The tool will have a mobile app that allows users to easily report their location and signal quality. The app will use the device's GPS to determine the user's location, and will allow the user to rate the signal quality on a scale of 1 to 5.
4. Implement the blockchain component: The collected data will be stored on the Ethereum blockchain using a smart contract. The smart contract will enforce rules around data sharing and privacy, to ensure that the collected data is only shared with other users in a way that does not allow for reverse triangulation.
5. Test and deploy the tool: Before launching the tool, it will be thoroughly tested to ensure that it is reliable and effective. Once it is ready for use, it will be deployed and users will be able to download the mobile app and begin contributing to the heat map of coverage information.

I hope this gives you an idea of how a blockchain-based crowd-sourcing tool for gathering and sharing user-device feedback on coverage information could work. Please let me know if you have any additional questions or need further guidance.
